title: William S. Schwartz
text:
William Samuel Schwartz (February 23, 1896 – February 10, 1977) was an American artist who lived and worked in <a href="Chicago">Chicago</a>.
Biography.
Schwartz was born in <a href="Smarhon">Smorgon</a> in <a href="Belarus">Belarus</a> (then in the <a href="Russian%20Empire">Russian Empire</a>) to Samuel Schwartz and Tauba Reznikoff. At the age of thirteen, he moved to the nearby city of <a href="Vilna">Vilna</a> to attend art school. Four years later, he emigrated to the United States and eventually enrolled in the <a href="School%20of%20the%20Art%20Institute%20of%20Chicago">School of the Art Institute of Chicago</a>. After graduating, he put his art career on hold to concentrate on a budding career as an <a href="opera">opera</a> singer. When Schwartz returned to painting, he distinguished himself with dreamy, symbolist works and abstractions that tended to bewilder viewers. He also scandalized conservative audiences with numerous <a href="lithographs">lithographs</a> of nude women. During the <a href="Great%20Depression">Great Depression</a>, Schwartz became an artist on the <a href="Federal%20Art%20Project">Federal Art Project</a> payroll. Working under the supervision of Increase Robinson in Chicago, he painted <a href="Regionalism%20%28art%29">Regionalist</a> works showing the countryside and small-town American life. It was not until the early 1940s that Schwartz returned to painting the esoteric imagery for which he had become known. Greatly influenced by European <a href="surrealism">surrealism</a>, Schwartz painted strange biomorphic forms and apocalyptic scenes in many of his works.
He became a well-known figure in Chicago, mostly due to his memorable handlebar mustache and eccentric persona. He was also one of a group of prominent Chicago artists—including <a href="Ivan%20Albright">Ivan Albright</a>, Malvin Albright, and <a href="Aaron%20Bohrod">Aaron Bohrod</a>—that hung out at Riccardo's Restaurant and Gallery during the 1940s and 1950s. In his final years, Schwartz returned exclusively to painting <a href="abstract%20art">abstracts</a>; these paintings are considered among his best work. Schwartz began suffering from <a href="Alzheimer%27s%20disease">Alzheimer's disease</a> around 1970 and died in Chicago on February 10, 1977.
The <a href="Art%20Institute%20of%20Chicago">Art Institute of Chicago</a> and the <a href="Joslyn%20Art%20Museum">Joslyn Art Museum</a> in <a href="Omaha">Omaha</a> have several of Schwartz's works in their permanent collections.
